conclusion: The problem involves analyzing how the shadows (A, B, C, D) of four objects change in position and size when the light source moves backward above the objects.
When the lamp is shifted straight backward, all four shadows slide forward in the picture (toward the camera/toward the bottom edge of the floor).
When the lamp is shifted straight backward, all four shadows become larger.
When the lamp is shifted straight backward, the outlines of the shadows do not change (ring stays a ring, square stays a square, rectangle stays a rectangle, triangle stays a triangle).
The increase in shadow size is greatest for the tallest object (C) and smallest for the flattest object (D).
Shadow A is ring-shaped.
Shadow A slides forward when the lamp moves backward.
For shadow A, the outside diameter grows, the inside hole grows by the same scale factor, and the ring keeps the same thickness ratio.
Shadow B is a small square.
Shadow B slides forward when the lamp moves backward.
For shadow B, the length of each side increases proportionally, so it stays a square but covers a larger area.
Shadow C is a long rectangle.
Shadow C already points toward the camera; when the lamp moves backward, it stretches even farther in that direction.
For shadow C, the length grows markedly, the width changes very little, so the rectangle becomes still longer.
Shadow D is triangular and corresponds to the paper plane.
Shadow D slides forward when the lamp moves backward.
For shadow D, all three sides enlarge by the same factor; the triangle keeps its shape but covers a slightly larger area.
Because the plane is very thin, the change in shadow size for D is noticeable but less dramatic than for C.
Moving the point light backward increases the horizontal distance between the light and every object while keeping the vertical height almost the same.
The projection lines meet the floor farther from the objects, so the shadows are cast farther forward and are stretched by a scale factor proportional to that horizontal distance.
